Hello! Thank you for being here to test StudyBuddy


The platform is still in its early stages and constantly evolving. Your support and feedback are necessary to build the application in the best way possible and help as many students as we can.

INTRO

At the bottom of the page, you can see a timer represented by a green snake.

The goal is to complete the study session, during which you have breaks (the apples) that you can take at any time.

BREAKS

By default, they last 5 minutes. Short breaks are meant to get some air, eat an apple, and rest your eyes while staying focused and unconsciously processing what you've studied so far.


We recommend avoiding distractions like social media and making the most of these well-deserved 5 minutes. Instead, take a walk to the bathroom or drink some water.

The break can be interrupted at any time.

MOTIVATION

Tracking study and break time has multiple benefits:


  • Clear distinction between study and break time
  • Awareness of how you managed your time
  • Resistance to distractions (phone, etc.) during study time

The timer is designed to follow the famous Pomodoro Technique:


A study session lasts 2 hours, divided between focused study and small breaks:


25 min study

5 min break


Repeat this 4 times


At the end, take a long break: this is the real break where you can finally scroll (if necessary) or take a walk and come back more energized.


You can also modify the settings if you want to follow different timings.


If you want to learn more about this technique, click the link.

We noticed, after interviewing several people, that the Pomodoro Technique has some limitations, including:

  • 25 minutes is too short for many people
  • Confusing
  • Some prefer to study for 1 hour straight (or more)
  • Not wanting to interrupt an exercise/chapter halfway for a break

For this reason, we created the Flexible Pomodoro, aiming to address these issues.

Now we think in terms of study sessions: a session normally lasts two hours and has 3 breaks of 5 minutes in between (same intervals as the classic Pomodoro). When a break is suggested, it will be indicated visually and with a sound, but you can take a break whenever you want according to your needs.

Still to be implemented, this is an option for those who want to study without the time constraints imposed by the previous techniques.


The goal is to have a summary of how much time was actually spent studying compared to breaks, possibly comparing it with your expectations.

The ToDo list can be displayed using the + button at the bottom right of the screen.


There are two types of ToDo:

  • Deadline: have a due date and are in the left column
  • Without Date: in the right column by default; you can add a date at any time and move it to the deadlines


Those with deadlines appear in the calendar on the home page.


Once marked as 'done,' they will be moved to the "done" list.

tasks.name: A normal task can become a deadline
tasks.notes: Just click on it, open this panel (which I would make a different color), and after adding a date, click the move to deadline button

tasks.name: And it ends up in a different column

postIts.content: The functionality of post-its is also very simple: just add them using the + button at the bottom right.

Clicking on the palette allows you to change the color.

Clicking on the X deletes the post-it.

Using keyboard shortcuts, you can also format the text:


  • With - you create a bullet list
  • Bold (ctrl or cmd + b)
  • Italic (ctrl or cmd + i)
  • Underline (ctrl or cmd + u)
You can add all the links that might be useful. Again, just press the + button at the bottom right.

In the calendar on the home page, you can add an event by clicking the point where you want to add it. 



You can then edit the title, start time, duration, color, and add notes related to the event. 



You can also drag the event vertically to move it within the same day and extend it to change its duration.
